6)...i hope that when your loved one reaches out for the help they so desperately need and deserve, the place welcoming them in offers exactly what they advertise, help, support, compassion, those steps to get their lives back, because right now they are often being exploited ...

3)..the person seeking help and the families that believed their loved on was in a safe place. recovery houses should be under the same rules & regulations that hospitals, nursing homes, daycare centres, etc are. regular random checks for compliance and if they fail - shut down..

2)....are in the business simply as a way to make money, exploiting those suffering, offering little or absolutely no support. these operators have no morals.they see an "easy mark" and they exploit those reaching out for help at their most vulnerable leaving devastation to ....

the often unseen or unknown to many people - this is a very real complication of this health crisis. harm reduction must be embraced across the board to avoid this devastating tragedy. when the brain is left without oxygen, brain cells die and a person is never the same.....
"some of our folks require up to five people to assist with care because they're so compromised," said jenkins.

http://www.cbc.ca/player/play/1633795651952/" psychiatric nurse malcolm jenkins manages the neuropsychiatry unit at st. vincent's langara, a complex care facility in vancouver where he works with people suffering severe brain damage due to an overdose.

many of the patients are under 50 and will need permanent care for the rest of their lives. while naloxone can reverse an opioid overdose if found soon enough - lack of oxygen results in brain cells dying - forever altering the life of the survivors and their families.
